text: Murkowski's who are, who is now toying with going independent.
speaker: SPEAKER_11

text: And most people would say, I think shoot almost every, uh, Republican district, if I'm not mistaken, went against her.
speaker: SPEAKER_11

text: And she is considered, you know, one of the most far leftist Republicans, um, in the country.
speaker: SPEAKER_11

text: And you'll have other, um, you know, uh, supposed Republicans that are saying, oh yeah, they're, they think it's fine.
speaker: SPEAKER_11

text: It's wonderful.
speaker: SPEAKER_11

text: Um,
speaker: SPEAKER_11

text: But the reality is it doesn't take that much thinking and looking to see that this has become a very partisan issue.
speaker: SPEAKER_11

text: The very fact that it has become a partisan issue where you have conservative groups that are saying, who are saying, listen, this is the first time in 50 years that we elected a Democrat to U.S.
speaker: SPEAKER_11

text: Congress after Don Young's term.
speaker: SPEAKER_11

text: And
speaker: SPEAKER_11

text: It was simply because of ranked choice and it was orchestrated also by Murkowski to win against Chewbacca.
speaker: SPEAKER_11

text: And so it seems to me that, you know, it's very difficult for the other for the proponents of ranked choice voting to say this is a nonpartisan thing, because, you know,
speaker: SPEAKER_11

text: the sides are kind of going against each other and not just the sides.
speaker: SPEAKER_11

text: It used to be like at the beginning with Mark baggage and the head of the Democrat party of Alaska being opposed to it.
speaker: SPEAKER_11

text: Well, then when they, they got it and they realized that it was to their benefit, then there's now changing their tune and saying, Oh gosh, no, it's the greatest thing in the world.
speaker: SPEAKER_11

text: It's so good for everyone.
speaker: SPEAKER_11

text: But then if I'm not mistaken, I've seen quotes from, you know, San Francisco and New York city and typically very, um,
speaker: SPEAKER_11

text: you know, progressive liberal communities who have said that, you know, it does marginalize those minorities in our community that are already struggling with issues of English as a second language or something.
speaker: SPEAKER_11

text: And this has just become an absolute nightmare for people that, let alone those who are English as a second language, but just for the general public to say, this is confusing.
speaker: SPEAKER_11

text: We don't even know what's going on when we go to the polls.
speaker: SPEAKER_11

text: Yeah, that's absolutely right.
speaker: SPEAKER_06

text: You know, I will say it may look like it's partisan, but in reality, it actually is bipartisan.
speaker: SPEAKER_06

text: It just depends on what jurisdiction or what state that you're operating in.
speaker: SPEAKER_06

text: You know, for example, the governor of California, Gavin Newsom,
speaker: SPEAKER_06

text: is against this, is against ranked choice voting.
speaker: SPEAKER_06

text: He said several years ago, he said, you know, that he was concerned about ranked choice voting and how it's often led to voter confusion and low turnout.
speaker: SPEAKER_06

text: And he said, this is far worse than a disease.
speaker: SPEAKER_06

text: So that was coming from the governor of California.
speaker: SPEAKER_06

text: And he actually vetoed a bill that would allow ranked choice voting statewide, you know, for
speaker: SPEAKER_06

text: And that may be because perhaps in California, the marginalized or the middle candidate may be Republican.
speaker: SPEAKER_06

text: Who knows?
speaker: SPEAKER_06

text: But it's just really interesting.
speaker: SPEAKER_06

text: I know the mayor of Washington, D.C.
speaker: SPEAKER_06

text: had also voiced opposition against it.
speaker: SPEAKER_06

text: There was a testimony from ACLU, which is a very liberal organization,
speaker: SPEAKER_06

text: They said that ranked choice ballots have suppressed voter turnout and resulted in decreased turnouts up to 8% in non-presidential elections, which I thought was really interesting.
speaker: SPEAKER_06

text: Oh, that's fascinating.
speaker: SPEAKER_11

text: Folks, we're chatting with Michaela Ensweiler.
speaker: SPEAKER_11

text: She's the chair of the Yes on to End Ranked Voting.
speaker: SPEAKER_11

text: We'll take a short break and
speaker: SPEAKER_11

text: come back and talk about some of the ways that they have really attempted to stop the effort from even being on the ballot.
speaker: SPEAKER_11

text: Stick around.
speaker: SPEAKER_11

text: We'll be right back after this short break.
speaker: SPEAKER_11

text: When peace like a river attendeth my way.
speaker: SPEAKER_08

text: kind of the two farthest ends of the spectrum in terms of geographically that have adopted this statewide.
speaker: SPEAKER_11

text: I know that there are some efforts underway to make it that way in a few states.
speaker: SPEAKER_11

text: Idaho, I think, is doing it and a few others.
speaker: SPEAKER_11

text: But, you know, if I'm not mistaken, there have been several states that have outright banned it altogether, either legislatively or through initiatives.
speaker: SPEAKER_11

text: And this is our opportunity.
speaker: SPEAKER_11

text: One of the things that you and I talked about previously was that this is not just a state issue because so many people are looking to Alaska and using Alaska as the example of, oh, gosh, everyone loves it up there.
speaker: SPEAKER_11

text: You know, it's just another flavor of ice cream and it's so easy and so much more helpful to voters, which is just not accurate.
speaker: SPEAKER_11

text: And so the way that we can send that message nationally is to have Alaskans vote.
speaker: SPEAKER_11

text: clearly vote now with their eyes wide open.
speaker: SPEAKER_11

text: Before, it was all about dark money, which is ironic because ask the people that are heading the other proponents of ballot measure to where is your money coming from?
speaker: SPEAKER_11

text: I mean, let's be very forthright about that.
speaker: SPEAKER_11

text: I don't think that they have done that or they're certainly not being very forthright about it.
speaker: SPEAKER_11

text: And so dark money is still very much at play.
speaker: SPEAKER_11

text: But what's also at play is can people
speaker: SPEAKER_11

text: you know, trust the system.
speaker: SPEAKER_11

text: And with this ranked choice voting, it's been something that has created a lot of distrust in the system, I think, and confusion.
speaker: SPEAKER_11

text: But one of the things that they have tried very hard in Alaska is to eliminate the option of people even having the ability to decide whether or not, okay, we've had a few years of this now, let's decide if we like it,
speaker: SPEAKER_11

text: They've come pretty hard at your efforts to put it on the ballot measure.
speaker: SPEAKER_11

text: Tell us a little bit about that.
speaker: SPEAKER_11

text: That's right.
speaker: SPEAKER_06

text: You know, we are an Alaska-led effort.
speaker: SPEAKER_06

text: Tens of thousands of Alaskans united together to sign a petition to repeal ranked choice voting last year.
speaker: SPEAKER_06

text: It was a really big project.
speaker: SPEAKER_06

text: Alaska is a big state, and you have to get a certain percentage from a certain number of districts
speaker: SPEAKER_06

text: throughout the state.
speaker: SPEAKER_06

text: So we had boots on the ground in every single district.
speaker: SPEAKER_06

text: There was over 700 volunteers that were collecting signatures.
speaker: SPEAKER_06

text: And a lot of Alaskans just wanted to see this issue on the ballot again to revisit it and have the opportunity to vote it out.
speaker: SPEAKER_06

text: Because you're right, a lot of Alaskans felt deceived.
speaker: SPEAKER_06

text: Initially, it passed by a
speaker: SPEAKER_06

text: very narrow margin.
speaker: SPEAKER_06

text: I believe it was 1%.
speaker: SPEAKER_06

text: And the messaging was about dark money versus ring choice voting.
speaker: SPEAKER_06

text: So a lot of people didn't even realize that they voted in this new system.
speaker: SPEAKER_06

text: So we are, and you're absolutely right.
speaker: SPEAKER_06

text: Every, when we, so we submitted our book
speaker: SPEAKER_06

text: to Division of Elections early on this year, back in January.
speaker: SPEAKER_06

text: And the statewide number of signatures that we needed was right around 26,000 signatures.
speaker: SPEAKER_06

text: And we submitted, it was right around 43,000.
speaker: SPEAKER_06

text: So this huge margin, which really voiced the Alaskan, the voice was so strong.
speaker: SPEAKER_06

text: It just was.
speaker: SPEAKER_06

text: very loud that folks wanted to see this on the ballot again.
speaker: SPEAKER_06

text: So Division of Elections did their tally and they were able to certify and confirm that we had enough signatures.
speaker: SPEAKER_06

text: The Lieutenant Governor, Nancy Dahlstrom, signed off on it and it's scheduled to be on the November ballot.
speaker: SPEAKER_06

text: But I will say every step of the way, there has been opposition and the lawfare has been real.
speaker: SPEAKER_06

text: You know,
speaker: SPEAKER_06

text: Scott Kendall, who is a he's an attorney here in Alaska and his Alaskans for Better elections group.
speaker: SPEAKER_06

text: They ended up suing the state to disqualify the repeal of ranked choice voting from the November ballot.
speaker: SPEAKER_06

text: And every single step of the way, the judge has actually the latest decision was granted just the other week.
speaker: SPEAKER_06

text: It ended up in favor of our group that worked to collect the tens of thousands of signatures over the course of the year.
speaker: SPEAKER_06

text: Alaskans for Better Elections and this attorney, Scott Kendall, and his group, they had hired moles and spies to infiltrate our efforts.
speaker: SPEAKER_06

text: They posed as signature gatherers.
speaker: SPEAKER_06

text: A lot of them went into...
speaker: SPEAKER_06

text: you know, the areas where the signature gatherers were, like the fair, different places of business, just to take pictures.
speaker: SPEAKER_06

text: Some of the volunteers were actually harassed as well.
speaker: SPEAKER_06

text: But, yeah, they just wanted to check up on the books.
speaker: SPEAKER_06

text: Sometimes the books were left unintended, and I'll just – and I'll get into that, but –
speaker: SPEAKER_06

text: at the end just a couple of dozen petition books were disqualified by the judge you know a lot of those books just had a page or half a page you know there wasn't enough to throw it off the ballot there was plenty of buffer um to keep this campaign moving forward but one claim made by the opposition was that there was a notary that had notarized over 60 booklets and her
speaker: SPEAKER_06

text: Unknown to her, her notary seal had expired.
speaker: SPEAKER_06

text: She had no idea.
speaker: SPEAKER_06

text: She actually thought she had submitted all the paperwork online, filled out all the forms, but she had no idea.
speaker: SPEAKER_06

text: And so they, the opposition said that, you know, why would Division of Elections release those books so that the signature gatherers can fix them when they could have thrown them out?
speaker: SPEAKER_06

text: Um, and division of elections to my understanding, they've done this in the past where they've allowed, you know, if there's a mistake on the date or the year or whatever it is that they've allowed, um, folks to come back in and just correct that little mistake.
speaker: SPEAKER_06

text: It's not, it's not, um, you know, it was not the intent to, um, be nefarious.
speaker: SPEAKER_06

text: There was no corruption.
speaker: SPEAKER_06

text: It was just an innocent mistake.
speaker: SPEAKER_06

text: Another example that the opposition brought up was they said there was absolutely no way a person could collect over 500 signatures in a day.
speaker: SPEAKER_06

text: And that just wasn't the case.
speaker: SPEAKER_06

text: You know, that was completely unfounded because our signature gatherers went to the state fair, the Palmer train Depot gun shows.
speaker: SPEAKER_06

text: People were lined up to sign these books.
speaker: SPEAKER_06

text: Right.
speaker: SPEAKER_06

text: Oftentimes they'd have multiple books on a table and,
speaker: SPEAKER_06

text: Because the lines were pretty steady during that time.
speaker: SPEAKER_06

text: And then another example was that they brought up was there was some business owners who were in charge of petition books.
speaker: SPEAKER_06

text: They left them unattended when they left the room.
speaker: SPEAKER_06

text: And the opposition was saying, you know, you have to be in the presence of your book the whole time and witness the folks that are signing petitions.
speaker: SPEAKER_06

text: signed the petition.
speaker: SPEAKER_06

text: So those books were dismissed, which is fair.
speaker: SPEAKER_06

text: But even with the dismissal of those books, there was plenty of signatures for the campaign to move forward.
speaker: SPEAKER_06

text: Well, yeah, that, you know, it's amazing how, you know, it's like whatever that Shakespeare, maybe you protest too loudly, you know, rather than, you know, building their arguments and
speaker: SPEAKER_11

text: in support of ranked choice voting, they really went out of their way to try to utilize all of these strategies to stop the effort from moving forward.
speaker: SPEAKER_11

text: And, you know, as if someone, because we were involved, Alaska County Council, as you know, was involved with, you know, a statewide initiative.
speaker: SPEAKER_11

text: And it's not easy.
speaker: SPEAKER_11

text: I mean, it's unbelievably difficult, actually, because you have to go by district in very remote areas.
speaker: SPEAKER_11

text: And,
speaker: SPEAKER_11

text: But we had at that time, that was 2010, the parental modification initiative that we successfully passed and unfortunately got overturned by the state Supreme Court, wrongly decided.
speaker: SPEAKER_11

text: But we experienced the same kind of thing and we never really had, even Planned Parenthood at that time wasn't out there trying to say, oh, Bob, you know, who has four booklets on a table and people in line to sign, they didn't think of that as a problem because of course you can manage
speaker: SPEAKER_11

text: four booklets.
speaker: SPEAKER_11

text: You're sitting there watching.
speaker: SPEAKER_11

text: You're in the presence of these people.
speaker: SPEAKER_11

text: They're signing it.
speaker: SPEAKER_11

text: And it just seems crazy.
speaker: SPEAKER_11

text: And in some ways, in a weird way, it's almost like encouraging because, yeah, it's desperate and they're doing everything they can to stop a democracy from happening and letting Alaskans decide on ranked choice voting.
speaker: SPEAKER_11

text: But it also shows you the level of desperation that they have.
speaker: SPEAKER_11

text: And so, gosh darn, you know, I mean, maybe that's an indication that they don't have very good case statements.
speaker: SPEAKER_11

text: You know, I think you and I have talked before that Mark Begich has changed his tune.
speaker: SPEAKER_11

text: I don't know about the former Alaska Democrat Party chair who at the time when it was passed initially was opposed to it.
speaker: SPEAKER_11

text: But those kinds of things, I think, demand attention.
speaker: SPEAKER_11

text: You know, I'd love to have Mark Begich on the show at some point and say, hey, listen, you were very clearly against this.
speaker: SPEAKER_11

text: What has changed your mind?
speaker: SPEAKER_11

text: And
speaker: SPEAKER_11

text: I think even Democrat folks need to hear from folks like Begich and the Democrat Party why all of a sudden you changed your tune when before you thought it was so nefarious or so wrong.
speaker: SPEAKER_11

text: Folks, we're chatting with Michaela Inswell.
speaker: SPEAKER_11

text: We'll be right back for our final segment right after this.

text: I'm a grandfather.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: Love to watch the grandkids grow and learn.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: Two boys and four girls, two college graduates, one in grad school, and three more about to start college.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: All earn scholarships coming out of high school.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: You can tell our family puts a huge premium on education.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: That's why I want to talk to you grandparents who have young grandchildren starting as young as three or four up through kindergarten or first and second grades.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: I want to talk about Holy Rosary Academy right here in Anchorage.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: It's known nationally for starting children at an early age and preparing them academically, socially, and morally for success in later grades.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: In short, they get a strong base to start their educational journey.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: Of course, parents are busy people, so maybe you could talk to your children about how you can help your grandkids to a superior education.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: So learn more.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: Are you considering a second mortgage?
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: Hi, I'm Chuck Bentley with my Money Life from Crown.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: Bankrate.com reports that the average American homeowner with a mortgage has just shy of $300,000 in home equity.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: This increased among this group by $24,000 just since the fourth quarter of 2022.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: Nearly 50% of mortgaged residences have a loan balance that's less than half the home's value.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: Second mortgages are available to those with positive home equity.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: These loans are means of financing maintenance or improvements to your property.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: These are taken in addition to a primary mortgage.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: They're called second because in the event of bankruptcy or foreclosure, they're paid off after the original mortgage.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: Cash is given and secured by equity in the home.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: So what is equity?
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: It's the difference between a home's value and how much you owe on it.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: For example, a house worth $300,000 with a remaining $200,000 mortgage has an equity of $100,000.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: Home equity increases with each mortgage payment.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: Monthly mortgage payments are required on both loans.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: A second usually has a higher interest rate than a primary mortgage.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: They're helpful when cash is needed, but can be risky.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: They increase debt and the possibility of foreclosure.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: Plus, that higher interest rate must be seriously considered.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: Don't assume you can sell your house and cover both mortgages if the unexpected occurs.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: I recommend having a healthy emergency fund and only using a second mortgage if absolutely necessary.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: And if you're thinking about a second mortgage because of mounting credit card debt, let Christian Credit Counselors help.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: They can create a debt management plan that works for you.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: For more information, visit crown.org slash ccc.
speaker: SPEAKER_01
